author: kannan-ravi
message: feat(curriculum): added interactive examples to How to Use the Attribute Selector to Target Ordered List Elements with the type Attribute? lesson (#63137)

files.patch:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ challengeType: 19 dashedName: how-to-use-the-attribute-selector-to-target-ordered-list-elements-with-the-type-attribute --- -# --description-- +# --interactive-- When working with ordered lists in HTML, the `type` attribute allows you to specify the style of numbering used, such as numerical, alphabetical, or Roman numerals. @@ -23,23 +23,47 @@ The `type` attribute can be set on an `ol` (ordered list) element to control the Here's how you can use the attribute selector to target an ordered list with a specific `type` attribute: +:::interactive_editor + +```html + +
    +
  1. Item 1
    2. +
  2. Item 2
    3. +
+``` + ```css ol[type="A"] { color: purple; font-weight: bold; } ``` +::: + In this example, the CSS rule will apply purple text and bold font weight to any ordered list that uses uppercase alphabetical numbering, which is specified by `type="A"`. Similarly, you can target ordered lists that use lowercase Roman numerals by selecting those with `type="i"`: +:::interactive_editor + +```html + +
    +
  1. Item 1
    2. +
  2. Item 2
    3. +
+``` + ```css ol[type="i"] { color: green; } ``` +::: + This rule will change the text color to green for any ordered list that uses lowercase Roman numerals. The ability to style ordered lists based on their `type` attribute gives you greater control over the appearance of lists in your document, allowing for customization based on how content is structured.
